newsitem.title: USA: Safety board readies plan on Boeing planes - WSJ.
newsitem.headline: Safety board readies plan on Boeing planes - WSJ.

text.p: The staff of the National Transportation Safety Board is preparing a series of wide-ranging safety recommendations affecting Boeing Co's 757 and 737 airliners, The Wall Street Journal reported on Friday.
Government and industry officials said the proposals were near completion. They would call for separate changes in both equipment and pilot training involving the two planes.
If eventually mandated by the Federal Aviation Administration, the measures likely would cost the industry tens of millions of dollars, the newspaper said.

As a result of last December's fatal crash of a 757 owned by AMR Corp's American Airlines into a mountain near Cali, Colombia, the board's staff is ready to recommend widespread installation of the most-advanced ground collision warning systems in large U.S. commercial aircraft, people familiar with the agency's deliberations said.
The recommendations are likely to call for a gradual phase-in of the devices in the 757s, and possibly other commercial aircraft as well.
The recommendations also call for changes in pilot training and operations, including for the 737.
The full board is slated to take up the issue in the next few weeks.
